awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: A Physics-Informed/Encoded Polymer Informatics Platform for Accelerated Development of Advanced Polymers and Formulations
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impacts of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project are to transform the way in which polymeric materials are developed. Adopting the most advanced artificial intelligence (AI) techniques, the proposed technology seeks to dramatically accelerate the exploration of new polymer formulations, efficiently and accurately discovering those with targeted performances and applications, and ultimately minimizing the time and the cost needed to develop new and superior functional materials. This technology will enable the targeted development of polymers for specific applications such as packaging or energy storage, while ensuring full recyclability. New polymer designs of this type can help alleviate the current global problem of plastic waste. Given that polymers are one of the most important classes of materials in use today, the impact of this SBIR Phase I project is expected to be significant and far-reaching. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims at transforming the state-of-the-art AI-based technology currently used to discover and design functional polymers. Since the beginning of polymer informatics about a decade ago, this AI-based approach has quickly become a powerful tool to design new functional polymers. At the center of this technology are the machine-learning models, trained on past data and used to evaluate the polymeric materials yet to be synthesized. Currently, the models are developed by purely “learning” the available datasets independently, ignoring numerous physics-governed correlations across data of different polymer classes and properties that come from different sources. Without proper awareness, the models can easily violate the relevant physic rules and render unphysical results, especially when the training data are not sufficiently large. In this project, the company will develop two deep learning architectures in which known and important physics-governed correlations are secured. The architectures will be the most advanced deep learning tools to combat the small and sparse data problems that are very common in and important for polymer informatics. The new technology is expected to significantly transform the development and deployment of functional polymers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project was proposed to transform the state-of-the-art artificial intelligence (AI)-based technology used to discover and design functional polymers and formulations. Emerged from about a decade ago, this AI-based approach has quickly become a powerful tool for the design of many new functional and sustainable polymers [1]. At the center of this technology are the machine-learning models, trained on past data and used to evaluate the polymeric materials yet to be synthesized. Traditionally, the models are developed by purely learning the available datasets independently, ignoring numerous physics-governed correlations across data of different polymer classes and properties that come from different sources. Without proper awareness, the models can easily violate the relevant physic rules and render unphysical results, especially when the training data are not sufficiently large. The company [2] proposed to develop two deep learning architectures, in which known and important physics-governed correlations are secured. Between these two architectures, one does not require the correlations to be expressed in terms of precise mathematical expressions while the other requires such expressions while being more enforced during the model development process. The architectures are the most advanced deep learning tools to combat the small and sparse data problems that are very common in and important for polymer informatics.

Upon completion of this SBIR Phase I project, the proposed architectures were developed, demonstrated, deployed, and enabled for use via a user-friendly graphical user interface. Furthermore, 6 stock models were trained on a big database curated during the project for 15 polymer properties and also released for users. The whole project was summarized in 2 scientific papers, one of them [3] is currenttly under review while the other will be submitted soon. The developments initiated and performed in this Project set the stage for a longer-term plan of the company, significantly transforming the current AI-based technologies, revolutionizing the design of functional and sustainable polymers, contributing to the sought-after carbon reduction, and supporting the transition to the net-zero greenhouse gas goals by 2050.

References

[1] H. Tran, R. Gurnani, C. Kim, G. Pilania, H.-K. Kwon, R. Lively and R. Ramprasad, "Design of Functional and Sustainable Polymers assisted by Artificial Intelligence," Nat. Rev. Mater., vol. 9, p. 866, 2024.

[2] "Matmerize, Inc.," [Online]. Available: https://www.matmerize.com.

[3] H. Tran, C. Kim, R. Gurnani, O. Hvidsten, J. DeSimpliciis, R. Ramprasad, K. Gadelrab, C. Tuffile, N. Molinari, D. Kitchaev and M. Kornbluth, "Polymer Composites Informatics for Flammability, Thermal, Mechanical and Electrical Property Predictions," arXiv, p. arXiv:2412.08407, 2024.


Last Modified: 12/19/2024
Modified by: Huan D Tran
